author: 8BrickMario
title: Get it while there's still time! You don't have a TARDIS, after all.
review:
One of the most exciting additions to Dimensions was Doctor Who,  here respresented by Peter Capaldi's Twelfth Doctor. How does it fare? 

Box/Instructions

The boxes for the line are rather nice, although I can't say I like the render of the Doctor on the top of the box. The instructions are practically pointless, but if you can't put together a minifigure, they're there for you. 

Parts

There are some nice pieces in this set, with the most notable being the sonic screwdriver and hair (also in the Ideas set) and the printed tiles for K-9 and the TARDIS doors. 

Minifigures

This version of the Twelfth Doctor in his standard outfit is exclusive. His head shows a stern expression, representing his personality pretty well, and the hair works nicely for him, even though it's been simultaneously designed to work for Dr. Peter Venkman. His torso and legs show his dark blue suit with the red accents, and his NFC base is decorated to match. 

The build

Again, the build is simple, but uses some nice techniques.

The completed model

The first model you build is K-9, the Doctor's robotic dog companion from the early seasons of the show. I think he looks superb, and is instantly recognizable. The TARDIS is the second build, perched upon a rocky terrain. The build here is more simple, but it still looks good. In-game, the TARDIS is larger, using a 4x4 footprint. 

Gameplay

The Doctor is a very useful character in the game, being able to hack technological panels, repair broken blue mechanisms, and shatter glass objects with his sonic screwdriver. After completing the level from this pack, the Doctor will go through his cycle of regenerations when he dies, cycling from the First Doctor, all the way to the Twelfth. 

K-9 and the TARDIS can both be upgraded to fire gold-cutting/melting lasers, and the TARDIS itself can be used to drop cargo into designated places and activate jet switches. The main draw for the TARDIS is its ability to travel through time and space to different areas. You can access its interior, though the control panel can only be used while playing as the Doctor, and the appearance of the interior is different based on which version of the Doctor you currently are. In the Doctor Who world, you can use the console inside to travel to the different areas, while you can also choose which regeneration you wish to play as. Certain platforms will also take the TARDIS to new areas. 

The level's gameplay is pretty unique. The plot is that Davros is attacking London in the future with the Dalek forces, and the gameplay focuses on traveling between different time periods to alter the reality in the future and allow you to solve puzzles (a similar mechanic is used in the Back to the Future world.  Some new enemies not present in the story level also appear. 

The adventure world is also unique, with the first goal being to connect all of the areas of the world. You need to destroy "dimensional discombobulators" to fuse the worlds of 2015 London, 19th century London, Trenzalore, Mars, Skaro, and Telos. Doing so will provide better navigation, and allow you to access more tasks. 

Overall opinion

There's a lot of value in this level pack. The experience is definitely going to be more worthwhile to serious Doctor Who fans (which I am not), but it's still enjoyable and worth your time to get it.

author: Odeinoichus
title: Digitally Explore all of Space and Time...
review:
Set #71204 Doctor Who Level Pack: LEGO Dimensions is what brought about LEGO Doctor Who, it and the Ideas set were both huge draws. This one features the ‘Twelfth’ Doctor and some very nice micro builds designed to be incorporated into the LEGO Dimensions video game.

Packaging

So as not to be repetitive I shall state that The Back to the Future Level Pack covers how each Level Pack looks packaging wise, this one has a really great look to it with all of the iconic Doctor Who inspired elements showcasing the content in the virtual world and real world quite nicely. I love the shot of Skaro opposite London’s Big Ben on the front, it is such a very iconic look to it.

Parts

The parts in this set include mostly common elements, but also a handful of nice printed pieces for the Tardis doors and some elements incorporated into K-9. Not a lot of parts in these Dimensions packs is one of the problems some have had at the prices, but honestly they work quite well for offering up some decent elements we wouldn’t have seen otherwise.

Minifigures

The Doctor: As we have seen The Doctor before, this Minifigure represents him in his official Twelfth Doctor costume, which is the only way to get him. He includes the Sonic Screwdriver and a host of detailed printing done for his coat and underclothing. His toy tag shows some printed elements in blue with red trim to represent the Tardis and features the Doctor Who logo of DW.

The build

Tardis: This is a very impressive little model, compared to the larger model in the Ideas set this is obviously a micro scaled build, but it was a real treat to construct… though there are some issues with it, the base is a bit of a cluttered mess, however it’s a necessary element to incorporate more parts than the model would otherwise require so you can have 3-1 models for the Dimensions play theme.

Laser-Pulse Tardis: The exterior of this build is relatively similar to the original model, the interior is modified to incorporate a different design of the overall model so you can build additional elements on the top to represent where the lasers are coming out. The base isn’t as built up with this version of the model.

Energy-Burst Tardis: This one, I feel, best represents the actual Tardis… actually all of them represent the Tardis fairly nicely, but they aren’t exactly show accurate. I suppose that’s the joy of LEGO models. I do prefer the base build for this model though simply because it isn’t as cluttered, and it does offer some better display options for the Tardis as a whole.

K-9: The build for this model is the most screen accurate version of K-9, he is a great looking build and I enjoyed it considerably. It can be detached from the base and be added to the interior of the Tardis from the Doctor Who Ideas set for an additional displayable character.

K-9 Ruff Rover: This build is really silly, it’s like K-9 is being turned into some sort of rideable vehicle, unfortunately the build does not include enough space to accommodate Minifigure.

K-9 Laser Cutter: If you don’t want a screen accurate version of the character you can’t go wrong with this build. It’s a bit silly looking as you construct it, but honestly it could be worse, it could be like the silly Hoverboard. At least this build actually has a build to discuss.

The completed model

Tardis & Alternate Builds: All three variations of the Tardis are pretty similar to one another at first glance, but the fact that the interiors use such a different build for the skeletons is truly amazing. I think my favorites though are the original Tardis and the Energy Burst Tardis, the second model just looks a bit silly with those laser blaster cylinders on the top, considering it doesn’t really look like what a Tardis should look like.

K-9 & Alternate Builds: K-9 himself is the best model, it’s the perfect looking buildable character and the secondary models do nothing really to impress, in fact the third version just looks utterly ridiculous… I’m not sure if either of them are accurate to any depictions on the television show, but for me personally, I’ll just stick to the main model and include K-9 with the Ideas set in my display once I finish playing the Dimensions game.

The Digital Content

The Level & Adventure World: Touted as an Adventure in Space and Time the official Level is called The Dalek Extermination of Earth. It’s an extensive adventure taking full advantage of the time travel element for the Tardis and The Doctor’s unique sense of humour. The Twelfth Doctor was recorded officially for all the lines, and there’s even a LEGO version of the opening theme, it’s a great love letter to the greatest creation of the BBC.

The Adventure World is vast and incorporates many locations, Modern Day London, Past London, Skaro and a few other worlds all smashed together. Dialogue was recorded for the characters and there is a lot of fun moments as you explore the world of Modern Doctor Who… there may be one or two references to Classic Who, unfortunately I’m not entirely certain which ones those can be as there is a lot of history to draw upon.

Vehicle & Character Abilities: The Doctor is loaded with abilities, as is befitting of a Time Lord. In-game he can Hack, use Technology switches, repair with the Fix-It ability, unleash a Sonar Smash, activate and solve Intelligence puzzles, and last but not least, he can regenerate into his past incarnations.

The Tardis can use Stealth, flies and can access flight docks and flight cargo hooks for flight based puzzles. It can also access Tardis docking stations to travel through time and space. Its second form adds the ability to destroy Gold LEGO objects and unfortunately the third form does not add any new abilities while losing the destroy Gold LEGO objects.

K-9’s first form can destroy Silver LEGO objects, his second form swaps out that ability to trigger Sonar Smash and his third form drops that ability to destroy Gold LEGO objects. Overall a very redundant list of abilities.

Overall opinion

I strongly recommend this Level Pack, it is must have if you want to finish everything in the game an experience everything. It’s also a very solid pack with some nice nods to Doctor Who lore and past adventures. The only downside in my opinion is the fact that K-9 just doesn’t work very well as a toy in-game, he has redundant abilities and the builds are all very weak after you start rebuilding it from the main model.

The Tardis however is just perfect, it’s a great mini-model and looks fun and in-game is really impressive. When it isn’t falling over on its side due to in-game glitches. Still the minor flaws are more than made up for by the entire package and I stand by my recommendation. For players of LEGO Dimensions this is a must have pack.
